reasoning:
First off, I’d tell you right away that Netflix is outside my circle of competence. I don’t make a habit of investing in content‐streaming businesses because they’re a blend of fast-changing technology, fickle consumer tastes and heavy programming costs. That alone makes me uneasy.

When I look for an economic moat, I want pricing power or enduring brand strength – think Coca-Cola or See’s Candies. Netflix has decent operating margins around 33 %, but its ROE (3.8 %) and ROIC (2.3 %) are weak, and it’s shown inconsistent earnings growth (down 65 % over the last ten periods). That’s not a durable competitive advantage in my book.

Management has issued shares recently, diluting existing owners, and they pay no dividend. I prefer teams that think like owners, hoarding cash and buying back stock when it’s cheap – GEICO and Wells Fargo come to mind.

On financial health, Netflix carries a 0.65 debt/equity load with choppy earnings. A strong balance sheet to me means low debt and consistent, predictable profits – neither of which Netflix delivers. The strong book value growth is a silver lining, but uneven earnings outweigh it.

Valuation is the final nail. My conservative DCF pegs intrinsic value around $126 per share. The market is trading well above that, giving a negative margin of safety of nearly 93 %. I’d rather wait for a much larger discount than chase a high-flying stock.

Long term, competition from Disney+, Prime, HBO Max and possible shifts in consumer habits pose big risks. I’d own a wonderful business at a fair price, not a fair business at a wonderful price. Compared to what’s out there in my portfolio – Coca-Cola’s brand, Apple’s ecosystem, BNSF’s rail advantage – Netflix simply doesn’t measure up.

In short, I say no. There’s no penalty for waiting, and plenty of better opportunities within my circle of competence.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 3.8%; High debt to equity ratio of 0.6; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of -65.1% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 1/10 periods >15%; Decent operating margins (avg: 44.2%) suggest some competitive advantage

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (5.7%, 5y), Stage 2 (2.8%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
